ground_truth: Gandhi is staring at the street, and from his point of view, we hold on a gaunt young, aged woman holding a baby wrapped in rags as threadbare as her sari, with another hollow-faced child leaning against her. A splendid peacock, its tail fanned in brilliant display, lords it on a velvet lawn while a woman in a sumptuous silk sari tries to feed it crumbs. Behind her, Gandhi's reception is in full spate with silver trays, tables covered in fine linen, Indian servants, a swimming pool, a small fountain, and the grounds filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries gathered with their wives to meet the new hero from South Africa. A beautiful and beautifully dressed woman, Mrs. Nehru, stands next to her distinguished husband, Motilal Nehru, and she nods lightly toward Nehru. Nehru is introducing Gandhi to two men, one tall, slender, and ascetic-looking but dressed impeccably, Jinnah, and the other with a haunting face, beard, flowing dark hair, the air of a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical, Prakash, whom we recognize from the opening sequence in Delhi at Gandhi's assassination. Gandhi bows to Jinnah and then looks a little startled at Prakash, who grins and makes the pranam to Gandhi. Gandhi nods and meets Prakash's gaze firmly, showing the first moment of the Gandhi of South Africa. Charlie Andrews touches Gandhi's arm, excusing himself to the others, and Gandhi bows to the others and is led off to an Indian bishop in full clerical robes. Behind him, we see Patel regaling a small group with some story of court or society, and as Gandhi leaves, Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash watch him clinically. Except for the servants, Gandhi is the only Indian male not in European clothes. Gokhale is pleased, and Gandhi is amused, sharing another grin. Gokhale has started to walk with him, looking at him intently and penetratingly, and although brusque, it is affectionate; we know he regards Charlie as Gandhi does. While Gokhale hasn't smiled, Gandhi and Charlie have, in a private, beautiful, and still moment. Gandhi walks along slowly, taking the pace of the ailing Gokhale, grinning self-deprecatingly, but Gokhale persists, pausing to look at Gandhi, and for the first time, he smiles. When he speaks, his voice is thick with feeling, his eyes watery with emotion, but he stares at Gandhi rigidly. Gandhi sits by a window in the dimly lit coach, as Ba sleeps on the seat next to him, with another member of the party next to her. Gandhi's solemn eyes are studying the huddled humanity in the rocking coach, while he writes in the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches, and outside, a broad alluvial plain stretches, with the river threading through it, purple and gold in the rising sun.

Behind him, we see Patel entertaining a small group with some anecdote of court or society, and as Gandhi departs, Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash observe him clinically. While Gokhale hasn't smiled, Gandhi and Charlie have, in a private, beautiful, and still moment. Gandhi strolls along slowly, adopting the pace of the ailing Gokhale, grinning self-deprecatingly, but Gokhale persists, pausing to look at Gandhi, and for the first time, he smiles. Gandhi sits by a window in the dimly lit coach, as Ba sleeps on the seat next to him, with another member of the party next to her. Ailing Gokhale's pace is taken by Gandhi as he walks along slowly, grinning self-deprecatingly, but Gokhale pauses to look at Gandhi and smiles for the first time. By a window in the dimly lit coach, Gandhi sits, as Ba sleeps on the seat next to him, with another member of the party next to her. By Gandhi, the huddled humanity in the rocking coach is studied solemnly, while writing is done by him in the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches, and outside, a broad alluvial plain stretches, with the river threading through it, purple and gold in the rising sun.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi gazes at the street, observing a gaunt woman with a baby in rags and another child leaning against her. A splendid peacock flaunts its tail on a velvet lawn while a woman in a silk sari feeds it crumbs. Nearby, Gandhi's reception is in full swing with silver trays, linen-covered tables, Indian servants, a pool, fountain, and Indian millionaires and dignitaries assembled with their wives to meet the new hero from South Africa. Mrs. Nehru, elegantly dressed, stands with her husband Motilal Nehru, nodding towards Nehru, who introduces Gandhi to Jinnah, tall and ascetic, and Prakash, with a poetic yet radical air. Gandhi bows to Jinnah, then is surprised by Prakash, who makes the pranam. Charlie Andrews excuses Gandhi to meet an Indian bishop. Patel entertains a group with a story, while Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash observe Gandhi closely. Gandhi is the only Indian male not in European attire. Gokhale, pleased and amused, walks with Gandhi, sharing a private moment, while Gandhi adjusts his pace to Gokhale's, prompting Gokhale's first smile. Gandhi's solemn eyes study the huddled passengers in a dimly lit coach as Ba sleeps beside him, writing amid the chaos of Third Class, with a river threading through the broad alluvial plain, purple and gold in the dawn.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi observes a gaunt woman with a baby and child in rags, while a peacock flaunts its feathers on a velvet lawn, with a woman feeding it. At a reception for Gandhi, Indian millionaires and dignitaries, including the Nehrus, attend. Nehru introduces Gandhi to Jinnah and Prakash. Prakash grins and greets Gandhi, who responds with a nod. Charlie Andrews excuses Gandhi, leading him to an Indian bishop. Patel entertains guests, while Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash observe Gandhi. Gandhi, unlike others, wears traditional Indian attire. Gokhale, fondly stern, walks and smiles with Gandhi and Charlie. Gandhi writes in the chaotic Third Class coach, watching the sunrise over a vast plain.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Gandhi stands quietly, his eyes fixed on the street beyond, and from his perspective, we see a gaunt, young, aging woman who is holding tightly to a baby. The child is wrapped in rags as threadbare as the sari she wears. Leaning against her is another child, whose face is hollow with want and need. Nearby, a magnificent peacock parades on a luxurious velvet lawn, its resplendent tail feathers fanned out in a dazzling display. A woman dressed in a sumptuous silk sari tries to entice the bird with crumbs. Behind this serene scene is a lively reception for Gandhi, brimming with activity. Silver trays are laden with delicacies; tables are elegantly adorned in fine linen. Indian servants move seamlessly among the guests. There is a glistening swimming pool accompanied by a small fountain, and the expansive grounds are filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries. They are gathered along with their wives to become acquainted with the new and celebrated hero from South Africa.

Among the elegantly dressed attendees stands a beautiful woman, Mrs. Nehru, gracefully poised next to her distinguished husband, Motilal Nehru. She nods lightly in acknowledgment toward Nehru, who is in the process of introducing Gandhi to two men. One of the men is tall, slender, and ascetic-looking, yet dressed with perfect elegance. This is Jinnah. The other man has a haunting face, a beard, and flowing dark hair, giving him the air of either a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical. This is Prakash, whom we remember from the dramatic opening sequence in Delhi at the time of Gandhi's assassination. Gandhi bows respectfully to Jinnah and then looks momentarily startled when his eyes meet Prakash's grin. Prakash makes the pranam gesture to Gandhi, who nods in return, firmly meeting Prakash's gaze, revealing the first glimpse of the resolute Gandhi of South Africa. 

Charlie Andrews gently touches Gandhi's arm, quietly excusing himself from the group. Gandhi bows to those around him and is led away to meet an Indian bishop, who is dressed in full clerical robes. As he moves on, Patel can be seen in the background, entertaining a small audience with an engaging story about courtly life or society. As Gandhi departs, Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash watch him with a clinical detachment. Notably, aside from the bustling servants, Gandhi is the only Indian male present who is not dressed in European clothes. Gokhale observes the proceedings with satisfaction, while Gandhi shares a moment of amusement with him, both exchanging a knowing grin. Gokhale has begun to walk alongside Gandhi, regarding him with an intense and penetrating gaze. Although he is brusque in demeanor, there is an underlying affection, for we understand that he holds Charlie in the same regard as Gandhi does. Gokhale has yet to smile, but Gandhi and Charlie share a private and beautiful moment of stillness, their smiles wide and genuine.

Gandhi moves along slowly, adjusting his pace to match that of the ailing Gokhale, who persists in his observant pause, once more fixing his gaze on Gandhi, and finally, for the first time, offering a smile. When Gokhale speaks, his voice is laden with deep emotion, and his eyes are watery, yet he maintains a rigid stare at Gandhi. Later, Gandhi is seated by a window in the dimly lit coach of a train, while Ba sleeps soundly on the seat next to him, with another individual from their group beside her. Gandhi’s solemn eyes take in the sight of the huddled humanity around him in the gently rocking coach. He writes amidst the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches, while outside, a vast alluvial plain unfolds, and a river meanders through it, painted in hues of purple and gold by the rising sun.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Gandhi stands quietly and contemplatively, his eyes fixed intently on the street beyond. From his point of view, we observe a gaunt, young, and aging woman who is clutching a baby with resolute determination. The child is wrapped in rags that are just as threadbare as the sari that she herself is wearing. Leaning against her for support is another child, whose face is hollow and etched with the unmistakable signs of want and need. Nearby, a magnificent peacock struts confidently across a luxurious velvet lawn, its resplendent tail feathers fanned out in a dazzling and eye-catching display. A woman dons a sumptuous silk sari and attempts to entice the bird delicately with a handful of crumbs. Behind this serene and picturesque scene, there unfolds a lively and bustling reception for Gandhi, brimming with vibrant activity. Silver trays are laden with an array of delicacies, and tables are elegantly adorned with fine linen. Indian servants move seamlessly and gracefully among the guests. There is a glistening swimming pool accompanied by a charming small fountain, and the expansive grounds are filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries. They are gathered together along with their elegantly dressed wives to become acquainted with the new and celebrated hero who has arrived from South Africa.

Among the elegantly dressed attendees stands a beautiful woman, Mrs. Nehru, who is gracefully poised next to her distinguished husband, Motilal Nehru. She nods lightly in acknowledgment toward Nehru, who is in the process of introducing Gandhi to two other men. One of these men is tall, slender, and ascetic-looking, yet dressed with perfect and impeccable elegance. This is Jinnah. The other man has a haunting and memorable face, with a beard and flowing dark hair, giving him the air of either an inspiring poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical. This is Prakash, whom we remember vividly from the dramatic opening sequence in Delhi at the time of Gandhi's assassination. Gandhi bows respectfully to Jinnah and then looks momentarily startled when his eyes meet Prakash's broad grin. Prakash makes the pranam gesture to Gandhi, who nods in return, firmly meeting Prakash's intense gaze, revealing for the first time a glimpse of the resolute Gandhi of South Africa.

Charlie Andrews gently touches Gandhi's arm, quietly excusing himself from the lively group. Gandhi bows graciously to those around him and is led away to meet an Indian bishop, who is dressed in full and traditional clerical robes. As he moves on, Patel can be seen in the background, entertaining a small and attentive audience with an engaging and captivating story about courtly life or society. As Gandhi departs, Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash watch him with a clinical detachment and a discerning eye. Notably, aside from the bustling and efficient servants, Gandhi is the only Indian male present who is not dressed in European-style clothes. Gokhale observes the proceedings with a deep sense of satisfaction, while Gandhi shares a moment of quiet amusement with him, both exchanging a knowing and conspiratorial grin. Gokhale begins to walk alongside Gandhi, regarding him with an intense and penetrating gaze. Although brusque in demeanor, there is an underlying affection, for we understand that he holds Charlie in the same high regard as Gandhi does. Gokhale has yet to smile, but Gandhi and Charlie share a private and beautiful moment of stillness, their smiles wide and genuine, marking their unparalleled camaraderie.

Gandhi moves along slowly and deliberately, adjusting his pace to match the slow steps of the ailing Gokhale, who persists in his observant pause, once more fixing his thoughtful gaze on Gandhi, and finally, for the first time, offering a heartfelt smile. When Gokhale speaks, his voice is laden with deep and profound emotion, and his eyes appear watery, yet he maintains a rigid and focused stare at Gandhi. Later, Gandhi is seated quietly by a window in the dimly lit coach of a train, while Ba sleeps soundly and peacefully on the seat next to him, with another individual from their group beside her. Gandhi’s solemn eyes take in the sight of the huddled humanity around him in the gently rocking coach. He writes diligently amidst the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches, while outside, a vast alluvial plain unfolds before him, and a river meanders through it, painted in hues of purple and gold by the rising and radiant sun.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi stands still, his gaze fixed intensely on the street, observing a scene that unfolds before him. His eyes catch a frail and gaunt young woman whose age seems prematurely advanced by hardship. She carefully holds a baby wrapped in ragged pieces of fabric, as threadbare as her own worn sari, while another child, equally hollow-faced and weary, leans against her for support. Meanwhile, in stark contrast, a magnificent peacock parades with its tail fully fanned out in a brilliant and colorful display. It dominates a lush, velvet-like lawn where it is the center of attention. A woman adorned in a lavish, sumptuous silk sari kneels nearby, attempting to coax the peacock by offering it crumbs. In the background, a lively reception is underway for Gandhi, attended by Indian millionaires and dignitaries, each accompanied by their elegantly dressed wives, all gathered to meet the esteemed new hero returning from South Africa. The scene is set with opulent silver trays and tables draped in fine linen, staffed by attentive Indian servants, while the luxurious surroundings feature a glistening swimming pool and a quaint fountain, contributing to the grandeur of the event. Among the attendees stands Mrs. Nehru, an embodiment of beauty and elegance, casually engaged in conversation next to her distinguished husband, Motilal Nehru. She subtly nods her head towards Nehru, who at that moment is engaged in introducing Gandhi to two significant figures. One is tall, slender, and ascetic in appearance but impeccably dressed—Jinnah. The other displays a haunting visage, sporting a beard and long, flowing dark hair, exuding the aura of either a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical—Prakash, a face familiar from the opening sequence in Delhi during Gandhi's assassination. With a respectful bow, Gandhi acknowledges Jinnah before momentarily pausing, appearing slightly startled as he turns to Prakash, who greets him with a wide grin and performs the pranam, a traditional gesture of respect. Gandhi, maintaining a firm and steady gaze, nods back at Prakash, revealing for the first time the persona of the resolute Gandhi from South Africa. At this point, Charlie Andrews lightly touches Gandhi's arm, offering an unobtrusive excuse to those around them as Gandhi bows again and lets himself be guided towards an Indian bishop garbed in full clerical robes. In the background, Patel captivates a small, attentive group with a compelling story from court or society, while as Gandhi moves away, he is still within the careful scrutiny of Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash, who watch him with clinical interest. Among the throng, Gandhi stands out as the only Indian male not clad in European-style clothing, a fact that pleases Gokhale, while amusing Gandhi himself, as they share a knowing, mutual grin. Gokhale, who starts to walk alongside Gandhi, regards him with a penetrating, intent stare. Although Gokhale does not smile, his brusqueness is tempered by a warm affection, particularly towards Charlie, whom he holds in mutual regard with Gandhi. The three share a private, serene moment marked by silent smiles. As Gandhi strolls onward, he accommodates his pace to the slower, more deliberate stride of the ailing Gokhale, grinning with self-deprecation. Undeterred, Gokhale halts to look directly at Gandhi, and for the first moment, he allows a smile to break through. When Gokhale finally speaks, his voice quivers with heartfelt emotion, his eyes wet, yet he maintains a steadfast, intense gaze upon Gandhi. Later, Gandhi finds a moment of solitude, seated by a window in a dimly lit coach. Beside him, Ba rests peacefully on the seat, with another member of their party situated next to her. Gandhi's solemn eyes wander over the huddled masses in the swaying coach, silently observing the cramped chaos typical of Third Class travel. Outside, the landscape unfolds in a breathtaking panorama—a vast, alluvial plain stretches out with a river winding its way across it, its waters glistening in hues of purple and gold under the soft light of the rising sun.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi observes the contrasting scenes of a gaunt, aged woman holding a baby and another child, set against a backdrop of opulence where a peacock dominates a lush lawn as a woman in a silk sari feeds it crumbs. Nearby, a reception in Gandhi's honor unfolds, featuring elegantly dressed guests, including Mrs. and Mr. Nehru. Nehru introduces Gandhi to Jinnah, who is slender and ascetic, and Prakash, a man with a haunting face and poetic demeanor, who greets Gandhi with a pranam. Gandhi responds to Jinnah with a bow and holds Prakash's gaze, signaling a shift to the Gandhi of South Africa. Charlie Andrews briefly interrupts to introduce Gandhi to an Indian bishop, as Patel entertains others nearby. Among the guests, Gandhi is distinct in his non-European attire, which pleases Gokhale, while Gandhi shares an amused grin. Gokhale, despite his brusque demeanor, shares a moment of affection with Gandhi, pausing to smile for the first time as he speaks with emotion. Later, Gandhi sits in a dimly lit coach, observing the crowded humanity around him while writing amid the chaos of the Third Class coaches. Outside, a vast alluvial plain unfurls, bathed in the purple and gold hues of the rising sun.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Gandhi is staring at the bustling street, and from his point of view in the vibrant city of Bombay, we hold on a gaunt young, aged woman holding a baby wrapped in rags as threadbare as her sari, a traditional garment worn by Indian women, with another hollow-faced child leaning against her. A splendid peacock, India's national bird, its tail fanned in brilliant display, lords it on a velvet lawn while a woman in a sumptuous silk sari imported from the finest weavers of Varanasi tries to feed it crumbs. Behind her, Gandhi's reception is in full spate with silver trays crafted by skilled local artisans, tables covered in fine linen, Indian servants who diligently maintain the household, a swimming pool, a small fountain, and the grounds filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries gathered with their wives to meet the new hero from South Africa, where Gandhi had led a successful civil rights campaign. A beautiful and beautifully dressed woman, Mrs. Nehru, stands next to her distinguished husband, Motilal Nehru, a prominent lawyer and leader of the Indian National Congress, and she nods lightly toward Nehru. Nehru is introducing Gandhi to two men, one tall, slender, and ascetic-looking but dressed impeccably, Jinnah, the future founder of Pakistan, and the other with a haunting face, beard, flowing dark hair, the air of a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical, Prakash, whom we recognize from the opening sequence in Delhi at Gandhi's assassination, where he played a pivotal role in the tumultuous events. Gandhi bows to Jinnah and then looks a little startled at Prakash, who grins and makes the pranam, a respectful Indian gesture, to Gandhi. Gandhi nods and meets Prakash's gaze firmly, showing the first moment of the Gandhi of South Africa, renowned for his philosophy of nonviolent resistance. Charlie Andrews, a close ally and English clergyman who supported Gandhi's work, touches Gandhi's arm, excusing himself to the others, and Gandhi bows to the others and is led off to an Indian bishop in full clerical robes, symbolizing the presence of various faiths at the event. Behind him, we see Patel, a future Deputy Prime Minister of India, regaling a small group with some story of court or society, and as Gandhi leaves, Jinnah, Nehru, and Prakash watch him clinically, analyzing the movements of a man they know will shape their nation's future. Except for the servants, Gandhi is the only Indian male not in European clothes, emphasizing his embrace of traditional Indian attire as a symbol of national identity. Gokhale, Gandhi's mentor and a senior leader in the Congress, is pleased, and Gandhi is amused, sharing another grin. Gokhale has started to walk with him, looking at him intently and penetratingly, and although brusque, it is affectionate; we know he regards Charlie as Gandhi does, a trusted confidant. While Gokhale hasn't smiled, Gandhi and Charlie have, in a private, beautiful, and still moment amid the gathering. Gandhi walks along slowly, taking the pace of the ailing Gokhale, whose health had been deteriorating, grinning self-deprecatingly, but Gokhale persists, pausing to look at Gandhi, and for the first time, he smiles. When he speaks, his voice is thick with feeling, his eyes watery with emotion, but he stares at Gandhi rigidly, conveying a mixture of pride and urgency. Gandhi sits by a window in the dimly lit coach, as Ba, his devoted wife Kasturba, sleeps on the seat next to him, with another member of the party next to her who assists Gandhi in his travels. Gandhi's solemn eyes are studying the huddled humanity in the rocking coach, a familiar sight in India's crowded train compartments, while he writes in the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches, known for their affordable fares but minimal comfort, and outside, a broad alluvial plain stretches, with the river threading through it, purple and gold in the rising sun, offering a serene view that belies the struggles of the people within.

Behind her Gandhi's reception is in full spate with silver trays tables covered in fine linen Indian servants a swimming pool a small fountain and the grounds filled with Indian millionaires and dignitaries gathered with their wives to meet the new hero from South Africa. A beautiful and beautifully dressed woman Mrs Nehru stands next to her distinguished husband Motilal Nehru and she nods lightly toward Nehru. Nehru is introducing Gandhi to two men one tall slender and asceticlooking but dressed impeccably Jinnah and the other with a haunting face beard flowing dark hair the air of a poet or a ruthlessly dedicated radical Prakash whom we recognize from the opening sequence in Delhi at Gandhi's assassination. Gandhi bows to Jinnah and then looks a little startled at Prakash who grins and makes the pranam to Gandhi. Gandhi nods and meets Prakash's gaze firmly showing the first moment of the Gandhi of South Africa. Charlie Andrews touches Gandhi's arm excusing himself to the others and Gandhi bows to the others and is led off to an Indian bishop in full clerical robes. Behind him we see Patel regaling a small group with some story of court or society and as Gandhi leaves Jinnah Nehru and Prakash watch him clinically. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Except for the servants Gandhi is the only Indian male not in European clothes. Gokhale is pleased and Gandhi is amused sharing another grin. Gokhale has started to walk with him looking at him intently and penetratingly and although brusque it is affectionate we know. he regards Charlie as Gandhi does. While Gokhale has not smiled Gandhi and Charlie have in a private beautiful and still moment. Gandhi walks along slowly taking the pace of the ailing Gokhale grinning selfdeprecatingly but Gokhale persists pausing to look at Gandhi and for the first time he smiles. When he speaks his voice is thick with feeling his eyes watery with emotion but he stares at Gandhi rigidly. Gandhi sits by a window in the dimly lit coach as Ba sleeps on the seat next to him with another member of the party next to her. Gandhi's solemn eyes are studying the huddled humanity in the rocking coach while he writes in the cramped chaos of the Third Class coaches and outside a broad alluvial plain stretches with the river threading through it purple and gold in the rising sun.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Einstein is observing the ocean, and from his perspective, we focus on a robust young, middle-aged man carrying a puppy wrapped in leaves as tattered as his cloak, with another round-cheeked kitten leaning against him. A massive elephant, its ears flapping in graceful display, commands it on a sandy beach while a child in a lavish cotton dress attempts to offer it seeds. Behind the child, Einstein's symposium is in full swing with golden plates, benches covered in coarse fabric, British butlers, a hot tub, a large sculpture, and the estate filled with British entrepreneurs and scholars gathered with their husbands to greet the new legend from Antarctica. A charming and elegantly attired man, Mr. Lincoln, stands beside his renowned wife, Mary Lincoln, and he gestures subtly toward Mary. Mary is presenting Einstein to two women, one short, stout, and contemplative-looking but dressed flawlessly, Monroe, and the other with a serene expression, adorned with short, curly locks, the aura of an artist or a fiercely dedicated leader, Emma, whom we recall from the initial scene in Paris at Einstein's declaration. Einstein nods to Monroe and then appears slightly surprised at Emma, who chuckles and gives the salute to Einstein. Einstein gestures and holds Emma's gaze steadily, revealing the first glimpse of the Einstein from Antarctica. Winston Churchill taps Einstein's shoulder, excusing himself to the others, and Einstein nods to the others and is guided away to a British cardinal in full military uniform. Behind him, we observe Jefferson entertaining a small crowd with some tale of battle or adventure, and as Einstein departs, Monroe, Mary, and Emma observe him analytically. Except for the butlers, Einstein is the only British female not in Asian attire. Franklin is delighted, and Einstein is entertained, exchanging another chuckle. Franklin has begun to stroll with him, gazing at him thoughtfully and intensely, and although abrupt, it is endearing; we know he regards Winston as Einstein does. While Franklin hasn't chuckled, Einstein and Winston have, in a quiet, delightful, and serene moment. Einstein meanders slowly, adjusting to the rhythm of the weary Franklin, chuckling modestly, but Franklin continues, pausing to gaze at Einstein, and for the first time, he chuckles. When he speaks, his voice is light with amusement, his eyes bright with energy, but he gazes at Einstein intently. Einstein lies beside a campfire in the brightly lit tent, as Joe snoozes on the blanket next to him, with another guest of the group beside him. Einstein's cheerful eyes are examining the scattered creatures in the swaying tent, while he sketches in the spacious tranquility of the First Class cabins, and outside, a towering mountain range towers, with the stream flowing beside it, red and silver in the setting sun.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi observes a gaunt woman with children in rags while a vibrant peacock and a woman in a silk sari contrast sharply with the luxury surroundings of a reception held for Gandhi. Indian millionaires, dignitaries, and notable figures like Mrs. Nehru, Motilal Nehru, Jinnah, and Prakash gather to meet Gandhi, who is introduced by Nehru. Gandhi, distinctively dressed in non-European attire, shares mutual respect with Jinnah and Prakash. Charlie Andrews discreetly connects with Gandhi, who is then introduced to an Indian bishop. Gokhale, who shares an affectionate yet brusque relationship with Gandhi, joins him for a profound and private moment, highlighting their deep connection. Later, Gandhi writes in a cramped Third Class coach, reflecting solemnly on the scenery and people around him, illustrating his humble journey against the vast, beautiful landscape.
